From: "Derek James" <djames@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Open Question Re: Implementation of Recessive Genes In NEAT Genome
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=183620858; y=47dFpwqM_t-aKLr7zd5o8Hm5fwGDCMmNiS7cjgQmT1i-_M0
X-Yahoo-Profile: blue5432

Andy,

Not that I know of...maybe Ken knows of NEAT implementations of recessive genes.

At one point with ANJI, we discussed going down this route. Since
genes in NEAT are traditionally monoploid (having only one set of
genes), but we thought about doing a diploid representation (two sets
of genes, one from each parent). You could then use dominant/recessive
markers for genes to determine which ones are expressed. You could
also experiment with blending, for example in connection weights,
where there is neither a recessive nor dominant expression, but some
blended function of the two (e.g. an average of the two). And if you
wanted to get really weird, you could implement polyploidy, where each
individual has any number of sets of genes (e.g. each individual could
have 10 parents).

I'd be interested to see some data from a direct comparison of an
implementation with and without recessive genes, so if you're going to
do it, let us know.

--Derek

On Nov 14, 2007 10:11 AM, afcarl2 <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Has there been any work to date on implementing recessive genes in a
>  NEAT genome? I am interested in embedding additional information in a
>  genome without disturbing the normal evolutionary progression, until
>  such time as the recessive genes may be activated, perhaps as a
>  mutation. Any direction towards prior work, preferably in the context
>  of NEAT, would be appreciated!
>  Thanks,
>  Andy
>
